#Text=Peeter Cornet
#Text=Peeter Cornet ( Pierre , Pietro , Peter , Pieter ) ( ca . 1570-80 – 27 March 1633 ) was a Flemish composer and organist of the early Baroque period .
#Text=Although few of his compositions survive , he is widely considered one of the best keyboard composers of the early 17th century . [ 1 ]
#Text=Life
#Text=Very little is known about Cornet 's life .
#Text=Much of the information comes from a letter by his widow . [ 2 ]
#Text=Cornet was born in Brussels , which was then the capital of Southern Netherlands , in the 1570s .
#Text=The family included numerous musicians , among them a violinist , singers and organists . [ 1 ]

#Text=From 1603 to 1606 Cornet worked as organist at Saint Nicholas Church , Brussels ; around 1606 he became court organist to Albert VII , Archduke of Austria and his wife Infanta Isabella Clara Eugenia of Spain , also in Brussels .
#Text=For one month , in March 1611 , Cornet was a canon at Soignies , but he gave up his canonry to marry . [ 1 ]
#Text=Cornet is listed as chapel organist in the surviving court account books from 1612 – 1618 . [ 1 ]

#Text=His colleagues included important English composers Peter Philips ( who acted as godfather to one of Cornet 's children [ 3 ] ) and John Bull , as well as fellow Flemish composers Géry Ghersem and Matthijs Langhedul .
#Text=Apparently Cornet was also active as an organ consultant and builder .

#Text=In 1615 he provided advice concerning the organ of St. Rumbolds Cathedral ( Sint-Romboutskathedraal ) in Mechelen , and in 1624 he signed a contract to build a choir division for the same organ . [ 1 ]
#Text=Works
#Text=Cornet 's surviving output is small and consists only of keyboard music : eight fantasias , two courantes ( with variations ) , a toccata , a setting of Salve Regina , and one of Tantum Ergo .
#Text=One of the fantasias , Fantasia del 5 . tuono sopra ut re mi fa sol la , survives incomplete .
#Text=The style varies from animated , bright music of the courantes , to elaborate polyphony in the fantasias and the mystical , religious feeling of the Salve Regina setting . [ 1 ]
#Text=The fantasias use the Italian ricercare structure , with its imitative treatment of the subjects in several sections .

#Text=However , Cornet prefers to use a large number of subjects ( up to six ) or relies on a double subject ( a subject the two halves of which can be used as separate subjects ) ; consequently , most of the fantasias are rather large works . [ 2 ]

#Text=The style shows the influence of English virginal music , with unexpected fast runs and characteristic figurations ( in some fantasias ornaments are even notated using the English symbol : two oblique bars ) , with the exception of wide skips , broken octaves , and other virtuosic figures such as those found in Bull 's and Farnaby 's music .
#Text=A characteristic feature is Cornet 's use of rhythmic changes .

#Text=In sharp contrast to his famed contemporary Sweelinck , who developed a pedantic , systematic approach to applying changes such as augmentation or diminution to the subject , Cornet prefers to only use the techniques where they seem appropriate , and avoids schematic treatment .
#Text=An augmented version of a subject , for instance , will not simply double all the note values , but rather double some , triple another , leave another intact , etc.
#Text=The presentation of the subject is almost always varied . [ 4 ]
#Text=The settings of Salve Regina and Tantum Ergo exhibit similar characteristics .
#Text=The former comprises five sections ( Salve , Ad te clamamus , Eia ergo , O clemens , Pro fine ) .

#Text=The first three are fugues on the initial motifs of the corresponding lines , the fourth is a cantus firmus setting with the melody first stated in the soprano and then in the tenor , and the fifth combines the subject and its inversion .
#Text=As in the fantasias , figural elements are seamlessly woven into the polyphonic fabric . [ 5 ]
#Text=Cornet 's courantes are both modelled on English examples .
#Text=One is followed by three variations of the entire piece . [ 6 ]

#Text=The only surviving toccata by Cornet consists entirely of various figurations , including among them the then-fashinable echo effect , frequently used by Sweelinck but only encountered here in Cornet 's oeuvre . [ 7 ]
